metadata.title: Israel approves settlement project that could divide West Bank

left: Israel has granted final approval for a settlement project in the occupied West Bank, which critics say will effectively divide the territory in two and threaten the future of a Palestinian state.
The Planning and Building Committee approved the project after rejecting last petitions against it, and it includes around 3,500 apartments to expand the settlement of Maale Adumim.
The settlement development has been under consideration for over two decades but was previously frozen due to U.S. pressure during earlier administrations.

The international community views Israeli settlement construction as illegal and a barrier to peace, despite the recent approval being characterized by some as a response to western nations recognizing a Palestinian state.
center: Israel approved a settlement project in the occupied West Bank that could divide the territory, impacting Palestinian hopes for statehood.
This settlement in E1, east of Jerusalem, has faced over two decades of delay due to U.S. pressure during prior administrations.
According to Bezalel Smotrich, 'Every settlement, every neighborhood, every housing unit is another nail in the coffin of this dangerous idea.'
The E1 settlement is seen as a threat to the geographical link between Ramallah and Bethlehem.
